title: EU competition commissioner says gig workers should bargain collectively
text:
Margrethe Vestager argued that workers for platforms like Uber “should be able to team up, to defend their rights,” adding that the commission has had discussions with national competition authorities about gig workers’ ability to form unions and negotiate wages. (Financial Times)

Talking points: The EU prohibits self-employed workers from forming collective bargaining agreements—under EU law, it would constitute a price-fixing cartel. However, Vestager is arguing that platforms falsely label their workers as self-employed contractors when they are actually employees. Vestager’s comments come as she steps into a rare second term as competition commissioner, as well as a role as the bloc’s digital policy tsar—an unprecedented combination of powers. Meanwhile, in an early sign that the commissioner’s notoriously hardline approach on Big Tech is having its intended effect, Google said it will now charge other search engines less money to appear on a “choice screen” where European Android-device users select a default search engine. A Google spokesperson confirmed that the change was developed in consultation with the European Commission.
